subject: Communication
title: Inoculation Theory: Vaccines for the Mind
description: A micro-lesson that makes Inoculation Theory: Vaccines for the Mind usable.

hook.text: You can vaccinate people against misinformation the same way you vaccinate against disease: small, weakened doses.

buildup.text: Inoculation theory (McGuire, 1961) exposes people to weakened versions of persuasive arguments so they build.

discovery.text: The game 'Bad News' lets players create fake news. After playing, they're significantly better at spotting real.

twist.text: Prebunking (inoculating before exposure) works better than debunking (correcting after belief is formed).

climax.text: Google, WHO, and governments now use inoculation campaigns. Short videos teaching manipulation techniques reduce.

punchline.text: The best defense against misinformation is a small dose of it, plus the antidote.

quiz.question: Why is prebunking more effective than debunking?
options: Building resistance before exposure prevents belief formation
